message.content:
We need to determine by how much the “Interest Receivables” account changed during the period. That is done by “adding up” (or “netting”) all the transactions whose type is “Interest Receivables” – and then – because an increase in a current asset (such as interest receivable) uses cash – the cash‐flow statement will show the “(Increase) Decrease in Interest Receivable” item as a negative number. (For example, in the sample the final answer was –2672.87 because the ending balance increased by that much relative to the beginning.)

Below you see a step‐by‐step outline of how to arrive at the result for the new dataset.

Step 1. Identify (only) the rows where the “type” is “Interest Receivables” (note that our record ID’s all begin with “Interest…”).

Step 2. List the “amount” values in the order they appear. In our new dataset these values are:

 • 2024‑01‑01 ("Interest20240101001"): 445.0  
 • 2024‑01‑02 ("Interest20240102002"): 445.0  
 • 2024‑01‑03 ("Interest20240103003"): 445.0  
 • 2024‑01‑04 ("Interest20240104004"): 313.28  
 • 2024‑01‑05 ("Interest20240105005"): 313.28  
 • 2024‑01‑06 ("Interest20240106006"): 245.3552  
 • 2024‑01‑07 ("Interest20240107007"): 245.3552  
 • 2024‑01‑08 ("Interest20240108008"): 215.1842  
 • 2024‑01‑09 ("Interest20240109009"): 215.1842  
 • 2024‑01‑10 ("Interest20240110010"): 215.1842  
 • 2024‑01‑11 ("Interest20240111011"): 215.1842  
 • 2024‑01‑12 ("Interest20240112012"): 215.1842  
 • 2024‑01‑13 ("Interest20240113013"): 215.1842  
 • 2024‑01‑14 ("Interest20240114014"): 132.50396  
 • 2024‑01‑15 ("Interest20240115015"): 132.50396  
 • 2024‑01‑16 ("Interest20240116016"): 132.50396  
 • 2024‑01‑17 ("Interest20240117017"): 132.50396  
 • 2024‑01‑18 ("Interest20240118018"): 132.50396  
 • 2024‑01‑19 ("Interest20240119019"): 132.50396  
 • 2024‑01‑20 ("Interest20240120020"): 132.50396  
 • 2024‑01‑21 ("Interest20240121021"): 132.50396  
 • 2024‑01‑22 ("Interest20240122022"): 132.50396  
 • 2024‑01‑23 ("Interest20240123023"): 132.50396  
 • 2024‑01‑24 ("Interest20240124024"): 132.50396  
 • 2024‑01‑25 ("Interest20240125025"): 6.37793  
 • 2024‑01‑26 ("Interest20240126026"): 6.37793  
 • 2024‑01‑27 ("Interest20240127027"): 6.37793  
 • 2024‑01‑28 ("Interest20240128028"): 6.37793  
 • 2024‑01‑29 ("Interest20240129029"): 6.37793  
 • 2024‑01‑30 ("Interest20240130030"): 6.37793  
 • 2024‑01‑31 ("Interest20240131031"): 6.37793  
 • 2024‑02‑01 ("Interest20240201032"): 6.37793  
 • 2024‑02‑02 ("Interest20240202033"): 6.37793  
 • 2024‑02‑03 ("Interest20240203034"): 6.37793

Step 3. Sum these amounts sequentially:

 – First three entries: 445 + 445 + 445 = 1335.0  
 – Next add 313.28 twice: 1335.0 + 313.28 + 313.28 = 1961.56  
 – Add two entries 245.3552 each: 1961.56 + 245.3552 + 245.3552 = 2452.2704  
 – Then add six consecutive entries of 215.1842 (from 2024‑01‑08 to 2024‑01‑13):  
  2452.2704 + (215.1842 × 6) = 2452.2704 + 1291.1052 = 3743.3756  
 – Then add nine consecutive entries of 132.50396 (from 2024‑01‑14 to 2024‑01‑24):  
  3743.3756 + (132.50396 × 10)  
  (Note: There are 10 such entries – from 2024‑01‑14 through 2024‑01‑24 – which add up to 132.50396×10 = 1325.0396.)  
  3743.3756 + 1325.0396 = 5068.4152  
 – Finally add the eight small amounts (each 6.37793) from 2024‑01‑25 to 2024‑02‑03: (There are 34–24 = 10 entries already counted? In our count from 2024‑01‑25 onward we have:  
  2024‑01‑25: 6.37793  
  2024‑01‑26: 6.37793  
  2024‑01‑27: 6.37793  
  2024‑01‑28: 6.37793  
  2024‑01‑29: 6.37793  
  2024‑01‑30: 6.37793  
  2024‑01‑31: 6.37793  
  2024‑02‑01: 6.37793  
  2024‑02‑02: 6.37793  
  2024‑02‑03: 6.37793  
  These 10 entries total: 6.37793 × 10 = 63.7793  
  Now, 5068.4152 + 63.7793 ≈ 5132.1945

However, recounting based on the step‐by‐step computed above we ended with 5264.69846. (The slight differences come from exactly how many “132.50396” entries we got. In our detailed count above, we had from 2024‑01‑14 until 2024‑01‑24 there were 10 entries. Let’s count explicitly the “132.50396” entries:
 – 2024‑01‑14: 132.50396  
 – 2024‑01‑15: 132.50396  
 – 2024‑01‑16: 132.50396  
 – 2024‑01‑17: 132.50396  
 – 2024‑01‑18: 132.50396  
 – 2024‑01‑19: 132.50396  
 – 2024‑01‑20: 132.50396  
 – 2024‑01‑21: 132.50396  
 – 2024‑01‑22: 132.50396  
 – 2024‑01‑23: 132.50396  
 – 2024‑01‑24: 132.50396  
That is 11 entries, not 10. So the total from these is 11 × 132.50396 = 1457.54356.
Then, adding the previous subtotal of 3743.3756 gives: 3743.3756 + 1457.54356 = 5200.91916.
Then the remaining 10 entries of 6.37793 gives: 10 × 6.37793 = 63.7793.
Thus final total = 5200.91916 + 63.7793 = 5264.69846.

So the ending balance in Interest Receivable increases by approximately 5264.70.

Step 4. In the cash‐flow statement the change in a current asset is “reversed” (an increase means cash was “used”). Therefore the “(Increase) Decrease in Interest Receivable” would be recorded as –5264.70.

Thus the final answer is:

{
  "(Increase) Decrease in Interest Receivable": "-5264.70"
}

Below is the answer in the required JSON format.

--------------------------------

```json
{"solution": {"(Increase) Decrease in Interest Receivable": "-5264.70"}}
```
